Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: We are given an event log with the following columns: Case ID, Timestamp, Activity, Resource, Region, Complexity. Steps: 1. Calculate the total duration for each case (from the first event Submit Claim to the last event Close Claim). 2. Identify cases that take significantly longer to complete. We can set a threshold (e.g., mean + 1 standard deviation) or look for outliers. 3. Analyze the attributes (Resource, Region, Complexity) for these longer cases to find patterns.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, lets try to find patterns: Hypothesis 1: High complexity cases require more requests for additional documents, which leads to longer durations. Indeed: Low complexity: 0 requests (cases 2001, 2004) Medium: 1 request (case 2002) High: 2 to 3 requests (cases 2003, 2005) This pattern is clear. Hypothesis 2: The number of requests for additional documents is directly related to the duration. We see: Case 2002: 1 request -> 1555 minutes Case 2003: 2 requests -> 2900 minutes Case 2005: 3 requests -> 4625 minutes So the more requests, the longer the duration. Why might that be? Each request for additional documents adds a cycle: waiting for the customer, then re-evaluation. This can cause significant delays.
